description: On March 12, 2020, Bulgaria's parliament also declared a state of emergency until April 13, 2020.
On March 3, The Bulgarian Parliament has approved to extend the state of emergency in Bulgaria until May 13, 2020.
On March 3, The Bulgarian Parliament has approved to extend the state of emergency in Bulgaria until May 13, 2020.

Bulgaria's Health Minister has issued a temporary ban on the entry into Bulgaria of third-country nationals outside the EU. The new order also bans the entry via all border crossings, with any kind of transport, regardless of their nationality, of persons coming from Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain, Northern Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg. An exception is made for Bulgarian citizens and their families.

description: A temporary ban on entry into Bulgaria of persons and vehicles coming from the Republic of Turkey through the three border checkpoints, comes into force on April 24. The ban will apply until the end of April 26. Exceptions will be made for cargo trucks, vehicles with special permits, automobiles transporting people who need medical treatment, as well as for vehicles performing humanitarian missions.

description: At an extraordinary video-conference meeting, on March 3, 2020, the Government of Bulgaria has approved two draft agreements that the Ministry of Health is about to sign with China National Pharmaceutical Foreign Trade Corporation. Bulgaria will buy Hydroxychloroquine Sulfate and Azithromycin Dispersible, needed to treat patients with COVID-19.

description: As of April 9, 2020, the Bulgarian Health Ministry together with the Bulgarian Red Cross initiated a campaign to recruit volunteers among those who study medicine to participate in the activities aimed to contain the Covid-19 pandemic.

description: On April 10, 2020, Bulgaria’s Cabinet approved a draft contract with South Korean company Osang Healthcare to buy 30 000 COVID-tests for a price of $303 000.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Bulgarian government annouced: All citizens who are an indoor or outdoor public places (including public transport, shopping facilities, parks, churches, monasteries, temples, halls, streets, bus stops, etc.) are obliged to wear a face mask for single or multiple uses or other means that cover the nose and mouth (including scarves, shawls, etc.) Public places are also the places and premises which are freely accessible and/or intended for public use. This also applies to places where public services are provided. The order is effective from 12.04.2020 up to and including 26.04.2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Bulgaria’s Minister of Health on April 30 issued an order to ban the export of certain medicines for the treatment of diabetes, schizophrenia and cancers. The export of certain ethanol-containing products is also prohibited. The ban is effective until the state of emergency is cancelled.

On April 1, 2020, Hasam Ademov, Member of the Bulgarian Parliament, had given a positive test for a coronavirus infection. For this reason, the work of the Bulgarian parliament was suspended for testing all MPs and the entire parliamentary staff for the virus.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of April 8, the Bulgarian Prime Minister stated that he had ordered mass testing for Covid-19 using rapid tests in the town of Bansko, which was quarantined in the course of 14 days.

description: Bulgaria will start large-scale testing for COVID-19 infections after securing sufficient test kits, easing a serious shortage, Health Minister Kiril Ananiev said on April 15, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of March 21, the Bulgarian Government decided to introduce checkpoints at the entry/exit roads to the district capitals and carry out checks on the purpose and destination of the journey. Passengers shall be admitted at the checkpoints only if the journey cannot be postponed for professional or work reasons, for reasons of health of the passenger or his/her family and for the purpose of returning to his/her place of residence or permanent residence.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
target_province: Policy is targeted to all district capitals in Bulgaria.

type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 20, 2020, Bulgaria's parliament has voted to allow the military to help curb the movement of people amid the coronavirus outbreak, with a mandate to use force if necessary.

description: As of 8 April, 2020, public transport in Sofia is running with altered working hours for optimizing its lines and guaranteeing service in the conditions of the emergency situation, Sofia municipality has announced.
type_text: The policy means to maintain the service of the public transport system in the conditions of the emergency situation. Therefore the working hours are reduced.

description: The Medical Expert Council with the Bulgarian cabinet has compiled a guide on successful Bulgarian and global strategies for coping with COVID-19. The 200-page report will be submitted for approval to the Bulgarian Ministry of Health and will then be available for use by all physicians in the country. This was announced on March 31, 2020.
On April 7, 2020 Bulgaria's Ministry of Health is introducing a National Information System for Combating COVID-19.

It was effected by an order of Bulgaria's Minister of Health on March 27 that all persons with confirmed cases of COVID-19 are to be quarantined for 28 days. Infected persons over the age of sixty or with serious additional health issues must be quarantined in a hospital.
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From April 6 all persons entering Bulgaria are subject to a mandatory two-week quarantine.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 13 the Bulgarian Ministry of Health is ordering a shutdown of shops, restaurants and entertainment establishments, until May 13. Supermarkets and pharmacies would remain open.

On March 13 the Bulgarian Ministry of Health is ordering a shutdown of shops, restaurants and entertainment establishments, until May 13. Supermarkets and pharmacies would remain open. From May 5, places can reopen, if the tables are outside and arranged with at least 2,5 meters of distance.
Open-air farmer's markets are closed preventively from 17 until 19 April by force of an ordinance issued by the minister of health in Bulgaria.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: Bulgaria has suspended the acceptance and registration of documents and conducting interviews for the acquisition, restoration and release of Bulgarian citizenship from March 17 until April 13.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: As of March 11, cultural and other large-scale indoor events in regions without confirmed cases of COVID-19 should be limited to no more than 250 people, who stay a meter apart from each other. In areas where cases of coronavirus have been confirmed, all large-scale indoor public events are banned.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: As of March 13, extracurricular activities for children and all public events in Bulgaria are suspended until March 29.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 20 Bulgaria introduces a ban on visits to parks, city gardens, playgrounds, sports grounds, outdoor and indoor public places. People would be allowed to enter parks to walk their dogs, but must not do so in groups. From May 5 individual sports outside and visits to swimming pools are allowed.
All extracurricular activities involving children and public events in Bulgaria are suspended until April 12.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: All extracurricular activities for children and public events in Bulgaria are suspended until May 13.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 20 Bulgaria introduces a ban on visits to parks, city gardens, playgrounds, sports grounds, outdoor and indoor public places. People would be allowed to enter parks to walk their dogs, but must not do so in groups.

An order that takes effect on April 27 allows visits to public parks and gardens by children up to 12 years ago, accompanied by at most two family members, between 9.30am and 6.30pm daily. People may still walk their dogs alone in public parks and gardens up to 9.30am and after 6.30pm.
As of May 1, 2020, the local authorities are requested to allow visits to national parks, nature parks, and mountains again by the Bulgarian government.

As of March 13, 2020, the Bulgarian Government suspends and forbids consultations for children and pregnant women, prophylactic examinations and immunizations, planned operations, including the transplantation of organs from living and carcass donors, and visits to all medical establishments shall be suspended.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police
